cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 4:8

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: The Employee's Post-Employment Duty of Confidentiality—The Employee's Right to Compete

para.paratext: Most employees will, in the absence of any improper activities prior to their departure from employment, be free to compete directly with and even to seek out customers of their former employer. Absent any stricter duties resulting from the express terms of an employment contract or the imposition of a fiduciary duty, an employee is free to make use of any knowledge and skills, as distinct from trade secrets or information of an obviously confidential nature, that they acquired during the course of employment.

This doctrine was expressly supported by the leading Canadian decision of the Supreme Court of Canada in Canadian Aero Service Ltd. v. O'Malley.[1] In Canadian Aero Service, the Supreme Court confirmed that the duty for most departing employees will be simply to have “respect for trade secrets and for confidentiality of customer lists”. Two other prominent cases, the Ontario High Court decision in Edgar T. Alberts Ltd. v. Mountjoy,[2] and the Manitoba Court of Appeal case of W.J. Christie & Co. v. Greer,[3] provide more detailed support. In RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc.,[4] the court reaffirmed that normally an employee's post-employment obligation is simply not to misuse confidential information.
In the Alberts case, the court set forth one of the most often cited passages on point:

It is now beyond argument that a departing servant has the right to compete with his former employer. He may do so by establishing a business in direct or partial competition and he may bring to that business the knowledge and skill which he acquired while in the former service, including knowledge and skill directly obtained from the previous master in teaching him his business …[5]

In W.J. Christie,[6] the court emphasized that: “There is nothing to prevent an ordinary employee from terminating his employment, and normally that employee is free to compete with his former employer.” DiFlorio v. Con Structural Steel Ltd.[7] confirmed that the duty of an ordinary employee to an employer is not a fiduciary one. It quoted W.J. Christie[8] with approval.
In Harding v. Myotech Therapeutics Inc.,[9] the court concluded:

This brings me to a consideration of what duty would have applied to Ms. Harding if she were considered an ordinary employee. In the absence of any restrictive covenant in the October 1, 1991 Agreement, the only restrictions on Beverly Harding, had she been an ordinary employee of Myotech without senior management responsibilities, would have been (1) not to make use of a client list taken from Myotech to solici[t] Myotech's patients, (2) not to use unfairly confidential information obtained from Myotech during her employment there to compete with Myotech; and (3) not to use any trade secrets of Myotech in competing against Myotech.

A director, officer or other key employee may, after leaving his or her principal, “compete” in the same industry without restriction provided that he does not do so unfairly.[10] In Cygnal Technologies Corp. v. Taylor,[11] the applications judge concluded that a fiduciary is certainly entitled to compete within the market place with its prior employer provided the fiduciary does not do so in an unfair manner, stating:

As an overriding proposition, departing employees have an absolute right to go into direct competition with their former employer and make use of the skills and general knowledge they accumulated during their period of employment: Edgar T. Elberts Ltd. v. Mountjoy, supra at 686. Competition per se by a departing fiduciary is not prohibited; only unfair competition is precluded.

In Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé,[12] Veolia sued its former employee, John Brulé, for breaching a non-competition covenant in his employment contract and for breach of fiduciary duty. The Court of Appeal concluded that the trial judge had erred both in finding that Mr. Brulé breached his non-competition covenant and in finding that he breached his fiduciary duty. The trial judge's conclusion that Mr. Brulé breached his fiduciary duty to Veolia by competing was anchored by his finding that Mr. Brulé was subject to an enforceable non-competition covenant and breached that covenant. The “unfairness” aspect of the competition was the breach of contract. As there was no breach of contract, this basis of liability fell away.[13]

Mr. Brulé did not dispute that he had owed a fiduciary duty to Veolia, and that he had continuing duties for a reasonable period of time after the end of his employment. The trial judge had also concluded that Mr. Brulé breached his duty to Veolia because he left Veolia with the binder of information with respect to prior bids, which the trial judge described as confidential information, and he did not tell Veolia that he was submitting a bid.[14]

In Cygnal Technologies Corp. v. Taylor,[15] the defendant as a director had quite appropriately, requisitioned sales reports of the plaintiff corporation for an upcoming board meeting. When the respondent resigned as a director, he took these documents with him. The respondent testified that they remained in his basement until he surrendered them to the plaintiff but that he did not use these documents in any bids for tendered contracts. The application judge, however, observed that the fact remains that the respondent had in his possession materials which contained sensitive information which could be beneficial to someone competing for tendered contracts. By failing to return the documents upon his resignation, the respondent has kept confidential information that could benefit him to the detriment of the plaintiff. The defendants conduct in keeping these documents may not have been significant if he did not decide to go into direct competition with the applicant five months later. The defendant, by keeping this sensitive information and then competing directly with the plaintiff five months later, was competing in an unfair manner.

In Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé,[16] the Court of Appeal differed from the view of the applications judge in Cygnal, supra, stating that mere possession of information cannot make the competition unfair if that information is not used. The fact that Mr. Brulé left Veolia with the binder of information with respect to prior bids and did not tell Veolia that Clean Water Works was going to bid did not amount to unfair competition. Moreover, the trial judge made a palpable error in inferring from the evidence that the information in the binder was “confidential”. The type of information in the binder was publically available. It was neither confidential nor sensitive.
Moreover, a former fiduciary employee who is free to compete is not required to tell his former employer that he is about to do so.[17]

One important exception to this principle is that a non-fiduciary employee who goes into business in conjunction with a fiduciary of the former employer will owe the same level of duty as the fiduciary.[18] The obligations of a fiduciary will be discussed in detail in sections 4:25 to 4:55.
Canadian Aero Service Ltd. v. O'Malley (1973), 40 D.L.R. (3d) 371 at p. 381, [1974] 1 S.C.R. 592.
Edgar T. Alberts Ltd. v. Mountjoy (1977), 79 D.L.R. (3d) 108, 16 O.R. (2d) 682 (H.C.J.).
W.J. Christie & Co. v. Greer (1981), 121 D.L.R. (3d) 472 at p. 477, [1981] 4 W.W.R. 34 (Man. C.A.).
RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. (2008), 298 D.L.R. (4th) 1 (S.C.C.).
Edgar T. Alberts Ltd. v. Mountjoy (1977), 79 D.L.R. (3d) 108, at p. 112, 16 O.R. (2d) 682 (H.C.J.).
W.J. Christie & Co. v. Greer (1981), 121 D.L.R. (3d) 472 at p. 477, [1981] 4 W.W.R. 34 (Man. C.A.).

DiFlorio v. Con Structural Steel Ltd. (2000), 6 B.L.R. (3d) 253 (Ont. S.C.J.), affd 21 B.L.R. (3d) 22 sub nom. DiFlorio v. Con Steel Ltd. (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused [2002] 3 S.C.R. vi sub nom. Con Steel Ltd. v. Rocca Steel Ltd.
W.J. Christie & Co. v. Greer (1981), 121 D.L.R. (3d) 472, [1981] 4 W.W.R. 34 (Man. C.A.).

Harding v. Myotech Therapeutics Inc., [1999] O.J. No. 158 (Gen. Div.), at p. 25 of the judgment. The duty of an ordinary employee not bound by a valid restrictive clause is set out further in Tomenson Saunders Whitehead Ltd. v. Baird (1980), 7 C.C.E.L. 176 (Ont. H.C.J.), at pp. 185-86 and 189.
Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé, 2012 CarswellOnt 2583, 2012 ONCA 173 (Ont. C.A.), at para. 33, leave to appeal refused 2012 CarswellOnt 12202 (S.C.C.).
Cygnal Technologies Corp. v. Taylor, 2005 CarswellOnt 3179, 45 C.C.E.L. (3d) 218, at para. 14.
Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé, 2012 CarswellOnt 2583, 2012 ONCA 173 (Ont. C.A.), at para. 33, leave to appeal refused 2012 CarswellOnt 12202 (S.C.C.).
Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé, 2012 CarswellOnt 2583, 2012 ONCA 173 (Ont. C.A.), at para. 35, leave to appeal refused 2012 CarswellOnt 12202 (S.C.C.).
Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé, 2012 CarswellOnt 2583, 2012 ONCA 173 (Ont. C.A.), at paras. 36-42, leave to appeal refused 2012 CarswellOnt 12202 (S.C.C.).
Cygnal Technologies Corp. v. Taylor, 2005 CarswellOnt 3179, 45 C.C.E.L. (3d) 218, at paras. 18-22.
Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé, 2012 CarswellOnt 2583, 2012 ONCA 173 (Ont. C.A.), at paras. 36-42, leave to appeal refused 2012 CarswellOnt 12202 (S.C.C.).
Veolia ES Industrial Services Inc. v. Brulé, 2012 CarswellOnt 2583, 2012 ONCA 173 (Ont. C.A.), at para. 43, leave to appeal refused 2012 CarswellOnt 12202 (S.C.C.).

See also Moore International (Canada) Ltd. v. Carter (1982), 40 B.C.L.R. 322 (S.C.), affd 56 B.C.L.R. 207, 1 C.P.R. (3d) 171 (C.A.); Canada Bonded Attorney and Legal Directory Ltd. v. Leonard-Parmiter Ltd. (1918), 42 D.L.R. 342, 42 O.L.R. 141 (S.C.A.D.).
